Metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) are coordination compounds with periodic structures composed of organic ligands, which act as links through coordination bonds, and metal ions or clusters, which act as nodes. In recent years, these materials have received considerable attention from researchers, particularly in the field of catalysis, due to several advantages such as large specific surface area, high functionalization of organic ligands, and uniform distribution. Their potential applications are promising. This paper provides an overview of recent advances in the application areas of MOF materials, with particular emphasis on multiphase catalysis and photoelectrocatalysis. The advantages of MOFs, including their tunable properties, high catalytic activity, and selectivity, are summarised. In addition, we provide insights into the future research directions and expected developments of MOFs in these applications, with the hope that the material design can be further optimized to enhance their efficiency and their intrinsic application potential can be explored. Graphical abstract It can be seen that MOFs have the following structural features for catalytic applications: (1) they can be used as catalytic sites using metal nodes in the MOF material; (2) they can be used as catalytic sites using organically linked chains of the MOF material; and (3) they can be used as a host for encapsulation of additional catalytic sites. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Organometallic frameworks Multiphase catalysis Electrocatalysts Photocatalysts Research progress Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Metal-organic framework materials (MOFs), also referred to as coordination polymers, are a type of porous ligands with ordered and spatial topological network structures [1]. Since the concept of MOFs was first proposed in the mid-1990s, a plethora of research literature has been published in the past two decades. MOFs are materials with unique physical and chemical properties, and they have a wide range of applications in various fields, including batteries, supercapacitors [2–6], catalysis [7–9], gas storage [10–12] and separation [13,14], sensing [15], and biomedicine [16]. MOFs have emerged as a functional material of great importance and have demonstrated their potential in various fields of research over the past few years. They have particularly shown promise in catalysis [17], which is a rapidly growing research direction. MOFs have shown great potential for use as multiphase catalyst materials due to several advantageous features [18]: (1) Tunability of pore shape and size. The organic ligands of MOFs show a rich diversity due to their tunability, as well as the bonding number of the central metal atoms and the connection with the ligands, which leads to the fact that the pore sizes and morphologies of MOFs can be easily adjusted; (2) The porous structure of MOF materials allows the incorporation of small molecules with catalytic activity (e.g., homogeneous catalytic molecules), nanoparticles of metals or metal oxides [19], and so on; (3) Diversity of functional groups. Organic ligands with specific functional groups can be obtained by pre-screening, and then MOFs with functional groups can be obtained, and the presence of functional groups will also affect the yield or selectivity of the catalytic reaction. As shown in the schematic diagram of nanostructured materials prepared based on metal-organic frameworks in Fig. 1 . However, MOF materials also have some drawbacks, such as structural instability, limitation of pore structure and functional ligands, complicated synthesis process, and poor electrical conductivity, which affect their full potential in practical applications [24,25]. To overcome these drawbacks, further improvement of their properties and the development of new functionalities are needed. However, due to the unique structure and properties of MOFs, they not only have a shape similar to that of a lattice but can also be assembled into a specific structure like molecules. In addition, MOFs also possess a small size, and it is easy to form a stable lattice at a certain temperature, therefore MOF materials can exhibit excellent catalytic activity, which is not available in other solid materials. MOFs offer several structural features that make them suitable for catalytic applications [26]: Firstly, metal nodes within the MOF material can serve as catalytic sites during the coordination process. Secondly, organically linked chains in the MOF material can also provide catalytic sites. Lastly, MOFs can act as hosts for encapsulating additional catalytic sites, such as nanoparticles (Fig. 2 ). In this study, we begin by classifying catalytically active sites based on their origin, encompassing coordination of unsaturated metal centers, functional organic ligands, as well as metal complexes or metal nanoparticle supports. Subsequently, we provide a comprehensive overview of recent research on the utilization of MOFs in multiphase catalysis. Additionally, we summarize the current applications of MOFs and their derivatives in the fields of electrocatalysis and photocatalysis. Multiphase catalytic applications of MOF materials MOFs are a new type of recyclable catalyst that combines the properties of homogeneous catalysts (e.g. uniform activity center, high activity) and non-homogeneous catalysts with high activity, stability, selectivity, and ease of recycling [27,28]. MOF materials perform multiphase catalysis through three main aspects: metal sites, organically bound ligands with bound catalytic sites, and catalyst supports for metal complexes and metal nanoparticles. Catalysis of unsaturated metal sites During the synthesis of MOF materials, the central metal coordinates not only with the ligands but also with the solvents used in the synthesis process. After high temperatures and other synthesis conditions, the solvent molecules will disappear and the exposed unsaturated metal sites have a favorable effect on the catalytic activity of the material itself [29]. In 2017, Shaabani et al. [30] reported the use of UiO-66 as a solid Lewis acid catalyst for the synthesis of nitrogen-containing heterocyclic scaffolds. The properties of UiO-66 were compared with those of other catalysts (e.g., RuCl3H2O, choline/urea chloride, cerium (IV) carboxymethylcellulose, etc.) in the one-pot synthesis of pyridine, quinoxaline, and imidazopyridine derivatives. The UiO-66 catalyst showed high yields in tests at low temperatures due to its high number of active sites, and its activity and structure remained unchanged after three cycles. Zhang et al. [31] used the Lewis acid site of UiO-66 as a catalyst for oxidative desulphurization (ODS). Under the optimized process conditions, the ODS conversion of dibenzothiophene could reach 100 %, but its recovery was still low. The catalytic performance of metal-organic framework (MOF) catalysts can be enhanced by incorporating functional groups into the bare metal framework. For instance, a pyridine group or amide is typically required as a base in a Knoevenagel condensation. Mistry et al. [32] fabricated two MOFs utilizing a room temperature slow diffusion reaction. The Cd sulfoisophthalate layer was bound with a pyridine conjugate to produce these compounds. All of them possess Lewis acidic sites, namely Cd metal centers, and basic sites such as acridazine, free pyridine, and uncoordinated thioredoxins. Consequently, they exhibit efficient catalytic activity both with and without solvents. Zhang et al. [33] prepared ultrathin Ni-MOF nanosheets using a polyvinylpyrrolidone-assisted approach. The nanosheets demonstrated activity in the Knoevenagel condensation reaction, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . In addition to the ligand-unsaturated metal centers formed by the MOF structure itself, we can also determine the location of the centers of the ligand-unsaturated metals by creating structural defects. Jiang et al. [34] successfully synthesized a MOF USTC-253 achieving unsaturated coordinated Al centers with a control strategy that resulted in an increased number of unsaturated coordinated metal centers. During the synthesis of MOFs, a suitable quantity of trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) was incorporated to facilitate its competitive coordination with the organic ligand. Thereby, the MOFs were successfully synthesized. While trifluoroacetic acid can be removed more easily following the formation of MOFs, it is possible to generate new Lewis acidic positions by creating further unsaturated, coordinated Al centers. After using trifluoroacetic acid to produce the defects, it was noted that the USTC-253-TFA had a considerably higher capacity for adsorbing CO2 compared to USTC-253. When catalyzing the cycloaddition reaction between carbon dioxide and propylene oxide, USTC-253-TFA demonstrated superior catalytic activity as a result of the presence of extra Lewis acid centers. Functional catalysis of organic ligands MOFs comprise multiple functional organic ligands which can be pre-modified before MOF preparation or post-synthesized after obtaining the MOFs. For instance, diverse functional properties can be achieved by modifying functional groups like -NH2 -SO3H -OH or -COOH on the benzene ring structure of the organic ligand in Metal-Organic Frameworks (MOFs). The ligands for MOF synthesis can comprise uncomplicated organic substances or intricate organic compounds like porphyrins. The properties of porphyrins, as an important bioactive substance, have been extensively studied, but mainly in homogeneous phases, thus limiting their applications. MOF materials incorporating porphyrin structures can be synthesized by bonding carboxylic acids to porphyrin rings and subsequently coordinating them with metal ions. The MOF material blends porphyrin's catalytic functionality with the properties of metal-organic framework materials. It is anticipated that the MOF material's pore structure will enhance its catalytic activity. Zhou et al. [35] produced PCN-222(Fe), a Zr-porphyrin MOF, which is illustrated in Fig. 4 . The creation of these MOFs exhibits striking parallels with cytochrome P450, both displaying the ability to catalyze the oxidation of organic substances through the use of hydrogen peroxide. The porphyrin ring is fixed within the MOFs' structure, preventing self-polymerization and significantly boosting performance in cyclic catalysis. PCN-222 (Fe) features a 3.7 nm-wide channel enabling effortless substrate entry into the pore and complete interaction with the catalytically active center. In the process of oxidizing biphenyltriol, PCN-222(Fe)'s Kcat value was several times greater than that of hemocrystallin. This indicates that PCN-222(Fe) has a significantly greater catalytic effect than hemocrystallin. MOFs can facilitate multiphase reactions involving homogeneous organic ligands and also provide binding sites for functional groups that are inaccessible in homogeneous reactions, such as Lewis acids and Lewis bases. Lewis acids and Lewis bases cannot coexist in homogeneous catalysts as they tend to combine and lose their acid-base properties. However, in MOF materials, the contact between Lewis acids and Lewis bases is restricted by the structure of MOFs, resulting in the production of MOF materials containing both Lewis acids and bases. De Vos et al. [36] produced UiO-66(NH2) through synthesis. These MOFs are susceptible to structural faults throughout their creation, resulting in an unsaturated state with a Zr center (exhibiting Lewis acidity), alongside the amino groups on their ligands displaying Lewis basicity. The researchers utilized a MOF material to catalyze the condensation reaction of benzaldehyde with heptanal and discovered that its catalytic activity surpassed that of Lewis acid catalysis in a single UiO-66. This provided further confirmation of the existence of a cooperative catalytic effect between the Lewis acid site and the Lewis base site. Catalysis as a metal complex or metal nanoparticle carrier Porous crystalline materials with special functions, known as MOFs, can be efficiently restricted within pore channels. Two techniques have been employed to create functionalized confinement of MOF materials. The first involves utilizing MOFs as a stable framework material to provide a space for their growth confinement and agglomeration prevention. This is currently the most common method in use. The process involves the gradual penetration of precursors, followed by decomposition and re-reduction [37]. The active centers are then synthesized directly within the pores of the skeleton. The sizes and shapes of these centers are controlled by the pore diameters, shapes, and structures of the MOFs. However, the morphology of the metal particles embedded in this method is relatively challenging to control. The second approach involves synthesizing the active center metal material from organic molecules, surfactants, and polymers. The material is then encased by constructing MOFs around it. This technique is highly effective at pre-composing and regulating the metal material's morphology. It also provides valuable insights into the synthesis of other NP/MOF materials. Eddaoudi et al. [38] suggest that, if porphyrins are added appropriately, they have the potential to be enclosed within the pores of MOFs, as illustrated in Fig. 5 . In the present study, rho-ZMOF cations with negative and positive charges were synthesized using porphyrins. The cations were able to enter the pores of MOFs through an electrostatic adsorption mechanism. The pore size of MOFs is notably larger than that of the porphyrin molecules, ensuring porphyrins are present in the pores. However, the window size of MOFs is relatively small compared to porphyrin molecules, resulting in a limited distribution of porphyrin molecules in the pores of MOFs. This method can load up to 60 % by weight of porphyrin. Moreover, the porphyrins situated inside the MOFs pores can be effortlessly metalized by the central N atoms that coordinate Mn, Co, Zn, or Cu, leading to porphyrins deeply entrenched with an array of metals proficient in performing diverse catalytic reactions. Thus, the oxidation reaction of cyclohexane was effectively promoted in this study, resulting in the production of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone through the utilization of catalysts that consist of Mn porphyrin MOFs and TBHP as oxidizing agents. Using MOFs to limit the domain or stabilize metal nanoparticles allowed us to prevent the migration and aggregation of metal nanoparticles in the absence of surfactant protection, thereby imparting superior catalytic properties. Common metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) utilized for the stabilization of metal nanoparticles include MIL-101(Cr), MIL-53, ZIF-8, UiO-66/67, and other relatively chemically stable MOFs. Fischer and his team [39] employed chemical vapor deposition (CVD) to infiltrate organic precursors of metals (Au/Pd/Cu) into MOF-5 pores, followed by reduction of the precursors to obtain Au/Pd/Cu@MOF-5 catalysts. These catalysts are capable of catalyzing reactions, including olefin hydrogenation and methanol-reforming. To decrease the usage of valuable metals and enhance the catalytic reaction effectiveness, Jiang et al. [40] first employed transition metals to fabricate MOFs-restricted bimetallic nanoparticles through a two-solvent technique. The impact of PdCo bimetallic nanoparticles on catalytic reaction performance was explored by cultivating them within MIL-101(Cr) pores developing a process for producing metal nanoparticles by utilizing the reducing properties of MOFs to reduce metal ions. Zhang et al. [41] synthesized a boron-imidazole MOF (BIF-20), in which boron coordinates with 2-methylimidazole and hydrogen atoms to form a B-H bond that possesses reducing properties capable of reducing metal ions. Ag@BIF-20 and Au@BIF-20 were synthesized using the same method, and their ability to catalyze the reduction of p-nitrophenol was verified. Electrocatalytic applications of MOFs Amidst the persistent consumption of fossil fuels and environmental issues resulting from their combustion, hydrogen fuel cells have gained attention as a promising power source, boasting of a high energy conversion rate and zero-emission impact. In a fuel cell, there are three reactions: precipitation of oxygen, precipitation of hydrogen, and reduction of oxygen. Electrocatalysis has been an important way to obtain clean energy in recent years, and the current commonly used catalyst is commercialized Pt/C. However, the disadvantages of Pt, including its steep cost and limited reserves, have led a significant number of researchers to investigate new catalyst alternatives. With a large specific surface area, rich and tunable topology, and porous properties, MOFs show promising applications in electrocatalysis [42–45]. Oxygen Evaluation Reaction (OER) field applications The electrocatalytic process that removes oxygen (OER) involves a four-electron transfer and produces various reaction intermediates, such as OH−, O −, and OOH−. Despite its complexity, the slow kinetics and high overpotentials associated with OER reduce the efficiency of electrolysis. Therefore, the development and synthesis of effective OER catalysts are crucial for enhancing energy efficiency. At this stage, noble metal oxides like RuO2 and IrO2 are considered to be the most efficient OER electrocatalysts, but the wide application of these catalysts is severely constrained due to their high price and limited resources [46]. The high specific surface area and porosity of MOFs have drawn the attention of many researchers to their use in fabricating OER electrocatalysts [47–50]. Two-dimensional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) possessing numerous surface uncoordinated metal sites can promote proton transfer, while the incorporation of varying metal constituents, e.g. Fe and Co, can elicit a collaborative influence and enhance catalytic prowess. Rui et al. [51] synthesized the bimetallic doped catalyst Ni-MOF@Fe-MOF by introducing electrochemically inert Fe-MOF nanoparticles into active two-dimensional Ni-MOF nanosheets. The material utilizes the advantages of two-dimensional nanosheets, which synergize Ni and Fe. In situ, the formation of NiO nanograins during the OER process leads to a substantial enhancement of the OER performance. An overpotential of just 265 mV is required to attain a current density of 10 mA/cm2 in alkaline conditions; an increase of around 100 mV in comparison to unmodified pure Ni-MOF. Wei et al. [52] nitially treated Zn-MOF at high temperatures. Following this, they loaded a sample of trinuclear Fe(III)2Fe(II) complexes into the Zn-MOF using a two-solvent method for a second pyrolysis, resulting in the production of Fe-NPs/GNCL, Fe-GNCL, and Fe2/Co1-GNCL. The key innovation of this method is the heteroatom modulation strategy (HMA), which replaces Fe(II) with other divalent metal ions such as Zn(II)/Co(II). This converts the polymerized iron atoms to a stable iron dimer. The incorporation of various metals produced synergistic effects between them. Consequently, the catalyst exhibited outstanding performance in the process of electrocatalytic oxygen precipitation. Table 1 compares the catalytic performance of MOF materials as electrocatalysts for the oxygen precipitation (OER) reaction with that of chalcogenide-based electrocatalysts [53–58]. By examining Table 1, it becomes apparent that the overpotential of MOF materials for OER electrocatalysts is lower than that of chalcogenide-type materials. Additionally, the OER activity and catalytic performance of the MOF materials are superior to those of chalcogenide-type electrocatalysts. MOF materials have significant potential for development as electrocatalysts for OER due to their high stability, large surface area, and porosity. Additionally, they offer easy energy band structure control and simpler preparation methods. Hydrogen Elimination Reaction (HER) field applications Hydrogen is regarded as an eco-friendly and sustainable energy source, and its production through water electrolysis is deemed a promising method for large-scale hydrogen production with potential for long-term development. Electrocatalytic hydrogenolysis reactions (HERs) involve multiple electron and proton transfer processes that produce adsorbed hydrogen derivatives. Due to their slow kinetics and low efficiency, these reactions require higher potentials to reduce reaction energy. The catalyst's role is to regulate intermediate molecule binding and electron transfer during the reaction, enhancing catalytic activity and efficiency [59]. Typically, noble metals like Pt display exceptional catalytic activity, however, their use as a catalyst in HER reactions is restricted on a large scale due to resource scarcity and high production expenses. Therefore, it is imperative to pursue low-cost and steady catalysts for the production of hydrogen in the commercial sector. Micheroni et al. [60] synthesized a nanometal metal-organic framework (nMOF) called Hf12 CoDBP through the use of hafnium chloride and cobalt dicarboxyphenylporphyrin (H2CoDBP) as a precursor. They subsequently modified the nMOF onto the surface of carbon nanotubes (CNTs), which included carboxyl groups, by covalent bonding. This resulted in the preparation of a new type of nMOF-loaded CNT composite material, named nMOF/CNT. The substance commences at 315 mV displaying a TOF of over 17.7 s−1, which notably boosts the conductivity of MOFs and demonstrates remarkable HER performance. For HER, the Gibbs free energy of the reaction intermediate state plays a crucial role. It is a vital part of the puzzle. Lin et al. [61]. employed MOF material Cu-BTC (BTC = 1, 3, 5-benzene tricarboxylic acid) as a precursor and carbonized it directly at 600 °C under nitrogen without adding any other carbon source. They subsequently conducted a solvothermal reaction to eliminate the Cu substance and induce nitrogen doping of the carbon frameworks. Ultimately, six-membered cyclic carbon materials with double graphite N doped into graphene-like lattice were formed after a cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycle. The inclusion of a carbon atom with two neighboring graphitized N atoms within a six-membered carbon ring minimizes ΔGH* to almost 0, consequently enhancing catalytic performance and hydrogen precipitation efficiency under acidic conditions. Table 2 compares the catalytic performance of MOF materials with that of chalcogenide-type electrocatalysts concerning their catalytic performance as electrocatalysts for hydrogen precipitation (HER) reactions [62–67]. A comparison of the data in Table 2 reveals that the overpotential of chalcogenide-type HER electrocatalysts surpasses that of MOF materials when used in HER electrocatalysts. This suggests that MOF materials exhibit superior HER activity compared to chalcogenide-type electrocatalysts, resulting in better catalytic performance overall. MOF materials used as electrocatalysts for the process of HER possess several key advantages including high activity coupled with low overpotential, structural tunability, strong stability, and high sustainability. Compared to chalcogenide-based electrocatalysts, MOF material electrocatalysts exhibit a greater potential for further HER reaction research. Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) field applications The electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a four-electron transfer process that produces H2O in acidic electrolytes and a variety of oxidative by-products in alkaline electrolytes. The reaction rate is slow, so catalysts must be applied to improve reaction selectivity, reduce by-product formation, and accelerate ORR kinetics. Consequently, the development and creation of high-performance ORR catalysts remain crucial for enhancing energy efficiency. Catalytic oxidation reactions have conventionally relied on precious metals as carrier catalysts, with their catalytic efficiency being strongly linked to particle size. The MOF materials configuration boasts a multitude of stable and organized metal sites, resulting in numerous active regions for chemical reactions. The framework-based cage structure efficiently resolved the issues encountered in precious metal-loaded catalysts such as low active metal dispersion, small particle size, and inadequate carrier binding ability, which results in catalyst migration and aggregation deactivation. The cage-like structure of MOFs maintains a small particle size and ensures a high degree of inter-particle dispersion, effectively limiting migration and maintaining a surface with high activity. This solution successfully solves the previously mentioned problems, making Au NPs with high catalytic activity ideally suited for oxidation reactions. Yi et al. [68] employed the MOF material ZIF-8 (also known as MAF-4) as a precursor and combined it with carboxymethyl cellulose polymer as a binder to produce a foamy composite through freeze-drying. Subsequently, high-temperature carbonization was employed to derive ultra-low-density MOFs from N-doped carbon aerogels formed from the composite. On one hand, the aerogel boasts a high mesoporous and macroporous ratio to expedite mass transfer, while its high conductivity greatly enhances electron transfer ability. On the other hand, the substantial nitrogen content induces a plethora of active sites, effectively activating oxygen. NCA-75 demonstrates a Tafel slope of 80 mV dec−1, in contrast to the Pt/C slope of merely 76 mVdec−1. NCA-75 catalyzes ORR through the four-electron pathway and exhibits a superior electron transfer number of 3.99 compared to Pt/C (3.95) in the experiment. The material exhibits good activity in electrocatalytic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Chen et al. [69] subjected aluminum-based MOF-MIL-121 to high-temperature pyrolysis to yield HMIL-121 with anhydride groups and both microporous and mesoporous structures. Divalent platinum salts were introduced via covalent modification at room temperature in aqueous conditions. This was followed by the high-temperature carbonization of Pt-HMIL-121, leading to the formation of Pt-HMIL-121-900, an electrocatalytic material that contains highly dispersed PT nanoparticles. It exhibited decent electrocatalytic efficiency in the oxygen reduction reaction, exceeding the catalytic activity of commercial catalysts by over two-fold. Table 3 compares the catalytic performance of MOF materials as electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) with that of chalcogenide-based electrocatalysts [19,70]. When examining the findings in Table 3, it is evident that the chalcogenide-type ORR electrocatalysts show greater onset potential and half-wave potential than the MOF materials, which are also utilized as ORR electrocatalysts. Additionally, the chalcogenide-type electrocatalysts exhibit superior ORR activity compared to the MOF materials as electrocatalysts, resulting in better catalytic performance overall. Although the catalytic activity of MOF materials as ORR electrocatalysts is not yet comparable to that of chalcogenide-type ORR electrocatalysts, they still have the advantages of high stability, versatility, durability, and environmental friendliness. Therefore, additional research and further development are required. Photocatalytic applications of MOFs The application of MOF materials for photocatalysis is based on their electron-hole separation behavior under photoexcitation, and this charge separation mainly originates from the charge jump and charge transfer of different components of MOFs [71]. In MOFs, the ligand and metal structure have the ability to produce and move charges when exposed to light stimulation. Secondly, MOFs have the ability to incorporate photosensitizers and catalytic components into a single material by immobilizing active sites on metal nodes or organic ligands or by encapsulating guest molecules within the pores. The considerable porosity of MOF offers swift transport and diffusion of substrates and catalyst products from the catalytic site. MOFs photocatalytic, as an emerging eco-friendly catalytic technology, presents significant potential in the realm of hydrogen production from cracked water and CO2 reduction reactions. Cracked water to hydrogen reaction field applications Photocatalytic cracking of water is generally based on inorganic semiconductors as catalysts; however, in recent years, research on the use of MOFs as photocatalysts for water decomposition has received increasing attention [72–74]. Owing to the porous nature and high specific surface area of MOFs, the utilization of active groups undergoes significant improvement. Meanwhile, various groups with different functions, such as photosensitizers and co-catalysts, can be introduced into the pores of MOFs through different methods and combined with MOFs in diverse ways to enhance the photocatalytic reaction performance of MOFs. Mori et al. [75] created a MOF comprising of Ru and p-phenylenedicarboxylic acid, which was utilized as a catalyst. Additionally, ruthenium terpyridine was employed as a photosensitizer, MV2+ was embraced as an electron transfer agent, whereas Na2EDTA was utilized as an electron-sacrificing agent, resulting in visible-light-induced photolysis of aqueous hydrogen. The TON value for hydrogen production was 8.16 following 4 h of light exposure. A comparison of the photocatalytic abilities between a nonporous complex and Ru-MOF, possessing a similar structure, highlighted a noteworthy decrease in catalytic activity. The turnover number dropped to 2.52, thus reaffirming the advantageous role that porous structures in MOFs play, promoting the photocatalytic process. García and his team [76] have achieved successful photocatalytic hydrogen production by using UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH2 as catalysts under light conditions beyond 300 nm, whilst selecting methanol as a sacrificial agent. Both UiO-66 and UiO-66-NH2 possess identical structural topology; However, the presence of the amino group results in an additional absorption peak within the visible region of UiO-66. This enhances light absorption properties, thereby enhancing the efficiency of catalytic hydrogen production. Furthermore, it is worth noting that while UiO-66 can only absorb UV light, UiO-66-NH2 is capable of absorbing some visible light. This feature renders UiO-66-NH2 more advantageous in practical applications. Causing structural faults in MOFs can also confer new functionalities. Ma et al. [77] suggested that structural imperfections in MOFs are instrumental in regulating the photocatalytic properties of the materials. Appropriate structural defects are seen to further enhance performance. Using zirconium-based MOFs (UiO-66-NH2) as a model for the study, UiO-66-NH2-X with a gradually increasing degree of defects was obtained by adjusting the amount of acetic acid (X stands for the molar ratio of the amount of the moderator acetic acid to the amount of the ligand used in the synthesis), and at the same time, the co-catalyst Pt nanoparticles were also introduced into the pores of the MOFs to obtain Pt@UiO-66-NH2-X. It was found that the photocatalytic hydrogen-producing activity of MOF materials with near-perfect structures was very low, whereas the activity was gradually increased by gradually increasing the amount of moderator in the synthesis and the degree of defects in the structure. However, if the moderator is used at a certain level, the photocatalytic hydrogen production activity of the material will decrease as its concentration continues to increase. In addition, the MOF material has good photocatalytic cycling stability. Feng et al. [78] prepared MOFs (mPT-Cu/Co) with photocatalytic properties by a multistep post-synthesis modification (PSMs) approach, and this novel MOF material consisted of copper photosensitizers (Cu-PSs) and Co catalytic activity centers. Due to the advantages of the MOF framework, as known from Fig. 6 , the close alignment of the Cu-PSs with the Co catalytic center greatly accelerates the electron transfer and also improves the photocatalytic activity. Applications in the field of CO2 reduction reactions In recent years, global environmental problems have become increasingly serious due to the greenhouse effect, and CO2 is one of the main gases that cause the greenhouse effect. Research has shown that using sunlight to catalyze the reduction of CO2 to produce low-carbon fuels [79] (e.g. CO2, CH3OH, etc.) and converting solar energy into chemical energy and storing and using it is one of the most effective ways to achieve sustainable energy development. MOFs are considered ideal for CO2 reduction processes due to their large specific surface area, high porosity, and excellent CO2 adsorption properties. Jiang and Zhang et al. [80] chose a stable MOF (PCN-222) consisting of porphyrin tetracarboxylic acid ligand and zirconium ions as a catalyst to achieve the catalytic reduction of CO2 to formate ions under visible light conditions as shown in Fig. 7 . Li et al. [81] successfully designed and synthesized a photocatalyst named MOF-808-CuNi, which has flexible bimetallic site pairs (DMSP), and this catalyst can efficiently catalyze the reduction reaction of CO2. The main highlight of this work is the use of MOF-808 with unsaturated ligand sites loaded with DMSPs with flexible properties, which gives the active sites of the catalysts flexible and dynamic capabilities to adaptively stabilize different intermediates during the catalytic reaction, preventing the intermediates from falling off to form by-products, and thus converting CO2 to CH4 in a highly selective manner. Conclusions and future outlook Recent applications of metal-organic framework materials and their derivatives in catalysis are briefly reviewed. Due to the highly regular structure of MOFs, the active centers are distributed throughout the MOF structure, and the porous nature of the MOF structure allows the reaction substrates to freely enter and exit the pores of the MOFs, giving MOFs both the characteristics of homogeneous catalysis and the advantages that are incomparable to homogeneous catalysis. MOFs have excellent catalytic performance in electrocatalytic reactions, which can be recycled and have high catalytic efficiency. Compared with other materials, MOFs show their significant advantages as catalysts: they have a large specific surface area and a porous structure, which can effectively adsorb the reaction substrate, enhance the interaction between the reaction products and the catalytic active sites, increase the reaction rate, and improve the utilization rate of the catalyst. The adjustable size of the micropores accelerates the transport of substances, while their high electrical conductivity greatly enhances the ability to transport electrons. In addition, MOFs and their derivatives have become a new hot spot in the current field of photoelectrocatalysis due to their unique structural properties and advantages. In photocatalysis research, most of the catalysts are semiconductors, whereas MOFs, due to their unique advantages, can be used to obtain a variety of novel framework materials by changing metal ions, ligands, and so on, resulting in a richer structure. In MOFs, the distribution of catalytically active sites is homogeneous and the pore structure is regularly ordered, and these factors contribute to the closer proximity of reactant molecules to the catalytically active center. However, although MOFs have made great progress in the field of catalysis, there are still many challenges in the synthesis and application of MOFs. In order to further expand the research and application of MOFs, we suggest the following development directions: (1) More systematic and in-depth studies to further understand the catalytic properties and reaction mechanisms of MOFs. This includes the use of advanced characterization techniques, such as in situ/atomic level characterization methods, to reveal the origin and influencing factors of the catalytic activity of MOFs; (2) Extending the temperature-adaptation range of MOFs to shorten the production time, reduce the production cost, and simplify the preparation process for efficient catalysis under a wider range of reaction conditions. This can be achieved by synthesizing more temperature-stable MOFs or by combining other materials; (3) Further expand the applications of MOFs, for example, MOFs can be used in biomedical fields. At present, there are many problems in the field of biomedicine, such as cancer diagnosis and treatment, etc. MOF materials can be used as drug carriers to achieve targeted drug delivery and slow drug release. At the same time, MOFs-based sensors can be used to realize research on gas detection, biochemical detection, etc. in the field of biomedicine; (4) More attention is being paid to combining MOFs with new materials to construct composites and derivative materials. For example, by combining MOFs with nanomaterials, biomolecules, etc., more diversified and function-specific applications can be realized. In summary, future research on MOFs should be devoted to more in-depth mechanistic studies, improving temperature adaptability, expanding diversified application areas, and promoting cooperation and knowledge sharing, in order to further discover and develop the potentials of MOFs in the field of catalysis and realize their wide application in practical applications. In conclusion, although MOFs face some challenges, we believe that with the joint efforts of researchers from various fields, the future of MOF catalysis will be bright. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) are coordination compounds with periodic structures composed of organic ligands, which act as links through coordination bonds, and metal ions or clusters, which act as nodes. In recent years, these materials have received considerable attention from researchers, particularly in the field of catalysis, due to several advantages such as large specific surface area, high functionalization of organic ligands, and uniform distribution. Their potential applications are promising. This paper provides an overview of recent advances in the application areas of MOF materials, with particular emphasis on multiphase catalysis and photoelectrocatalysis. The advantages of MOFs, including their tunable properties, high catalytic activity, and selectivity, are summarised. In addition, we provide insights into the future research directions and expected developments of MOFs in these applications, with the hope that the material design can be further optimized to enhance their efficiency and their intrinsic application potential can be explored.
coredata.dc:title: Current research status of MOF materials for catalysis applications
